author: @thedestroyerofhats
text:
Surely the tech level also matters, if your making thousands of world war 2 era tanks in a factory that was retooled from making something actual useful like cars using a ton of workforce there is utility. A bunch of people learned a bunch of skills directly applicable after the war and the facilities and capital stuff can probably be switched to be used for useful stuff later. 

Modern weapons aren't like that at all. Hyper specialized fiddly equipment made slowly and expensively at dedicated facilities built in peace time (which don't seem to be able to scale up very well when a war actually happens). They can't even turn the line off because then the capacity fades away almost immediately. Drone production and infantry equipment seems to have been the only thing that can actually scale. Like neither side has been able to scale up simple artillery shell production to necessary levels in 3 years.

author: @florianlipp5452
text:
Why war might stimulate production and thus GDP seems pretty obvious.
But GDP might be a misleading metric in this case.

Much better suited to measure economic prosperity (particularly in this case) would be NDP (net domestic product).

NDP = GDP minus depreciation of assets.
Therefore, NDP takes into account all the assets lost because of war, such as destroyed houses or infrastructure (as well as destroyed fighting vehicles etc.).
And frankly, I don't see how an acitivity that acively destroys assets can  be ultimately beneficial to the combined NDP of all combatants.

author: @Martcapt
text:
The drop in total factor productivity. Isn't it better explained by hinderance to use existing factors (some form of transaction costs) rather than that there are less factors?

Saying that the productivity of labor, capital, or both put together (total) has decreased because there is less of it seems strange, assuming decreasing marginal returns...

The production may have decreased, but it'd make sense for the productivity  not to by virtue of less of a factor

text: remember folks:  in the end stock market is a reflection of profit-making potential of companies. It is the exponential growth of the human knowledge, hence productivity, that drives the growth of the stock prices of the global stock market.  In the end, unless you think the world will collapse, with something like global thermonuclear war, then mankind will continue to march ever forward, along with the stock prices.  Invest for the long term and you can't go wrong, as if WW3 doesn't happen you will be rich, and if it does happens then wealth won't matter.

author: @tehcoolemu
text:
Easiest way to see that war can't be just an unmitigated economic positive: if it were, governments could just pretend to be at war all the time (or for whatever the optimal time period is determined to be). "Draft" a few percent of the population by paying them not to work any economically productive jobs. Ramp up production of war materiel to absurd levels, regardless of whether or not there's an actual need for it. (You can let the armed forces have live-fire exercises constantly, in which they can fire as many shells as they like, if you don't have the storage space.)

This is pretty obviously a sub-optimal allocation of resources (human and otherwise). During war, it's better than the alternative, so we do it anyway. But, "better than losing the war" is not at all the same as "better than there being no war."
video_title: The Impact of War on Markets and the Economy

author: @Philip271828
text:
It depends on where the war is happening. If you're Britain in the war of the Spanish Succession or the USA in the second world war, all the destruction happens somewhere else so much of your war expenditure can be retained for peacetime while your competitors  cannot, leaving you in an advantageous position. 
It's good that it has been done thoroughly but I don't think that armies marching across your country, destroying as they go, is bad for your economy is a great revelation. See also the practice of going on Chevauch√©e (John O' Gaunt), T√°in B√≥ C√∫ailnge or the Spanish Cabalgada of The War of the Two Peters.

In the most recent case, I suspect that it may have something to do with the failure of tariffs to work as hoped.
video_title: The Impact of War on Markets and the Economy

author: @thomasfoltin3832
text: Not sure if he said it.  But i feel that the 72% GDP growth during WWII for the USA is misleading.  GDP is Consumer spending+ business investment+ GOVERNMENT SPENDING+ net exports.  Gov spending skyrocketed on military and industrial output during WWII.  Normalized (Or Core) GDP takes out Net Exports and Gov Spending and is more recurring or organic.  This is a better gauge of how a ware truly impacts the people of the US economy.

author: @batie83
text: If as many as 60% of American adults read below a sixth-grade level, it is hardly surprising that ignorance has found fertile ground in the country. While low literacy does not equal stupidity, it undeniably creates an environment where nuance is drowned out by catchy slogans and complexity is easily sacrificed for spectacle. In a society where critical reading and informed analysis are uncommon, ignorance is not merely tolerated; it is often celebrated. Layer on the amplifying power of social media, a culture of anti-intellectualism, and the rise of celebrity-driven politics, and you have a nation where folly is not only visible but, disturbingly, venerated.

author: @Asleepshadow
text:
The great Islamic Scholar Ibn Khaldun said civilisations have five stages:

1. Foundation (Conquest and Establishment)
2. Consolidation (Power and Authority)
3. Expansion (Territory and Wealth)
4. Peak (Comfort and Luxury)
5. Decline (Decay and fragmentation)

I would argue that the West is in stage 5 now.

author: @ren-joo
text:
Did you heard about Floor Space Index (FSI), it is a regulatory formula used in urban planning that determines the maximum total construction area allowed on a plot of land. It is calculated by dividing the total built-up area of a building by the total area of the plot of land. This index helps control population density, influences land value, and ensures organized development by balancing built-up areas with open spaces within cities.

It‚Äôs not correct the if high rise buildings are more it won‚Äôt fall to recession

author: @Gaurav_Prakash
text:
My entire US portfolio of 15 American companies gave me 50% profit in 3 months. I have sold it and booked 50% profit in 3 months. Am I beating 99.99% of the funds or not?

Now parked the money in Fixed Deposits to invest after a significant correction in any asset which crashes. 

Guys, I believe you should not invest while everything is at all time high because periodic corrections and PE optimisation always takes place after a bull run.
I am not investing at these levels but booking profits.

Remember the Saying - "Sell when everybody is greedy and buy when everyone is fearful".

Please play safe with your hard earned money.üòÆ

The word "conspiracy" originates from the Latin word conspirare, which literally means "to breathe together".
 This etymology reflects the notion that people who conspire are united in thought and action, so closely aligned that they are metaphorically described as breathing in unison.
 The concept extends beyond the literal act of breathing, symbolizing a deep harmony and shared commitment, often described as "thinking in harmony".
 This shared breath represents a collective purpose, whether for positive or negative ends, and is central to the word's original meaning of agreement or unity.

author: @braxhartman
text: This video rightly bemoans the loss of shareholder democracy but completely missed one of the most important ways that it could come back: institutional pass-through voting. This allows the shareholders to direct how BlackRock and others vote on their behalf. For example, you can choose to let BlackRock vote on your behalf, choose a proxy firm like Glass Lewis or ISS vote for you (proxy advisory firms were also absent from this video), or choose your own vote.

text: Desde una perspectiva econ√≥mica, la estabilidad del Per√∫ se sustenta en un modelo de econom√≠a libre establecido en la Constituci√≥n de 1993, que fomenta la inversi√≥n y el crecimiento sostenido. author: @karlvonbahnhof6594
text:
I asked AI 
"What would be the consequences, if USA took over Greenland, analyze it and tell me your opinion?"

"In January 2026, intensified rhetoric from the Trump administration regarding the annexation of Greenland "one way or the other" has led experts and world leaders to analyze the potential for a catastrophic breakdown in international relations.

Geopolitical Consequences

Dissolution of NATO:¬†Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen and other European leaders have warned that a forced U.S. takeover would effectively end NATO. Attacking a fellow member state would violate the core principle of collective defense.

Global Isolation:¬†The U.S. would likely face condemnation from the UN General Assembly and lose its moral authority on the world stage. Allies such as France, Germany, and the UK have issued joint statements affirming Greenland's sovereignty.

Closure of Foreign Bases:¬†Analysts suggest that European nations might retaliate by closing critical U.S. military bases in their territories, severely hampering U.S. power projection in the Middle East and the High North.

Economic and Security Impacts

Market Instability:¬†Threats of annexation have already caused concern among institutional investors, with some Danish pension funds reassessing their holdings of¬†U.S. Treasuries.

Strategic Overreach:¬†While the U.S. seeks Greenland for its vast mineral wealth (including rare earth oxides) and its position in the "Golden Dome" missile defense system, critics argue these goals could be achieved through continued diplomacy rather than a costly occupation.

Internal Unrest:¬†Domestically, such an "unlawful order" could trigger a constitutional crisis, potential military resignations, and widespread public protests within the U.S..

Analysis and Opinion

In my opinion, a forced takeover of Greenland would be a strategic catastrophe for the United States. While the Arctic‚Äôs melting ice makes its resources more accessible, the "realist" case for acquisition is undermined by the fact that the U.S. already maintains the¬†Pituffik Space Base¬†in Greenland under existing agreements.

The cost of alienating Europe‚Äîtraditionally the bedrock of American security‚Äîoutweighs any perceived gain from territory that 85% of Greenlanders do not wish to yield to the U.S.. Instead of securing the Arctic, such an action would likely create a power vacuum that Russia and China would exploit, leading to a more dangerous and unstable "New Cold War"."

author: @sinatra7407
text:
China‚Äôs method delivers 3 times more olefin production from coal by slashing CO2 emissions

A new Chinese process cuts carbon dioxide emissions to near zero while tripling olefin output from coal.

Chinese researchers have developed a new method for creating coal-sourced chemicals that reduces carbon dioxide emissions while increasing yield and efficiency. In fact, they found that their new process can result in three times as much useful product.

More olefins, fewer carbon emissions

In other parts of the world, steam is used to convert oil or natural gas to make the same product, which has fewer steps but is equally inefficient in terms of energy and waste.

text:
The UN and many other multilateral orgs have hopelessly failed their initial purposes - 57 wars in progress globally by some accounts. The ICC is toothless, the UN has no mandate to investigate bio-weapons labs discovered (and admitted to exist) in Ukraine - to name a few.¬†Too many of these orgs are nothing more than "soft-power" influence tools to infiltrate sovereign countries by bad actors. Yes, there are some vital services mixed in - to grant cover for the more nefarious actions.
The Sustainable Development agenda leaves developing nations crippled in terms of energy independence, while the west enjoyed the hay-days of fossil fuel extraction in order to industrialize their regions, which leaves them leagues ahead on all fronts - and now the "wanna-do-the-"right"-thing" nations are left wanting with little financial support for their so-called green transition - while wind turbines are taken off-line in the west because it costs more to produce the energy supposedly yielded, and there are environmental concerns. South Africa exported 700% more coal to the EU a few years ago - while load shedding was shoved down the throats of South Africans. True story.
